questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer is configuring a Cisco wireless LAN controller and needs wireless multicast to use the 54Mbps rates. Which action meets this requirement?

discussion.content: C is correct, based on the offical guide, tip page 284, it clearly says they're transmitted at the highest mandatory data rate. So if 54Mbps is the highest mandatory data rate, then it will be the one used.
54Mbps rate in example is set to "supported" - that supports only unicast. Multicast needs mandatory state. In this case, only C seems logical

CAPWAP APs transmit multicast packets at one of the configured mandatory data rates.
 If reliable reception is a goal, multicast frames must be transmitted at a low data rate, by disabling the higher mandatory data rates. 
If support for high data rate multicast frames is required, it can be useful to shrink the cell size and disable all lower data rates, or to use Media Stream.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wireless-mobility/wireless-lan-wlan/81671-multicast-wlc-lap.html

Selected Answer: C
It is C. Multicast will use the lowest Manditory rate, so set 54Mbps to manditory will have the desired result without having to disable everything else.

comments.content: Actually, option D doesn't mention adding "mandatory" for 54 Mpbs, so without mandatory 54 won't be used. So... I guess then "c", although it isn't recommended to leave the others as mandatory.
I agree, you wouldn't want the other data rates to be set as mandatory too.

Provided answer D looks correct 
https://community.cisco.com/t5/wireless/wlc-settings-for-high-performance-cells/td-p/2298996#:~:text=never%20use%20two%20mandatory%20rates%2C%20you%20would%20only%20set%20one%20mandatory%20rate%20and%20multicast%20is%20sent%20at%20that%20rate
By disabling all below 54 Mbps only 54 Mbps will remain as supported

choices.B: Set all data rates below 54 Mbps to Supported.
choices.D: Set all data rates below 54 Mbps to Disable.

questions.question_text: A network administrator managing a Cisco Catalyst 9800 WLC must place all iOS connected devices to the guest SSID on VLAN 101. The rest of the clients must connect on VLAN 102 distribute load across subnets. To achieve this configuration, the administrator configures a local policy on the WLC. Which two configurations are required? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
Same as Question #141

C and E are the best answers based on this:

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wireless/catalyst-9800-series-wireless-controllers/215661-in-depth-look-into-client-profiling-on-9.html#toc-hId--520732385

choices.B: Add local profiling policy under global security policy settings.
choices.E: Enable device classification on global wireless settings.
choices.A: Assign a policy map under global security policy settings.
choices.D: Allow HTTP and DHCP profiling under policy map.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
In FlexConnect mode, WLANs must be properly mapped to VLANs at the branch office to function correctly. Creating a FlexConnect group and configuring WLAN-VLAN mapping ensures that the WLANs are correctly associated with the appropriate VLANs, allowing both WLANs to work in FlexConnect mode.

The other options are not the correct solutions:

B. Disable local switching on the WLANs: This would prevent WLANs from working in FlexConnect mode, which is not the desired outcome.

C. Map the AP group to the WLAN interface: This is not directly related to resolving the issue with FlexConnect mode.

D. Join the APs to a Cisco FlexConnect group: While this is necessary, it does not address the specific issue of WLAN-VLAN mapping required for WLAN B to work in FlexConnect mode.

questions.question_text: An enterprise has two WLANs configured on WLC. It is reported that when converting APs to FlexConnect mode, WLAN A works but WLAN B does not. When converting APs to local mode, WLAN B works, but WLAN A does not. Which action is needed to complete this configuration?

choices.A: Create a Cisco FlexConnect group with WLAN-VLAN mapping.
choices.D: Join the APs to a Cisco FlexConnect group.
choices.C: Map the AP group to the WLAN interface.
choices.B: Disable local switching on the WLANs.

choices.A: Predownload the new code to the APs.
choices.B: Use the Smart AP image upgrade feature.
choices.D: Execute parallel TFTP code upgrade on the APs via SSH.
choices.C: Allow the APs to download their code after WLC reboot.

questions.question_text: An engineer is planning an image upgrade of the WLC, and hundreds of APs are spread across remote sites with limited WAN bandwidth. The engineer must minimize the WAN utilization for this upgrade. Which approach must be used for the AP image upgrade?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
provided answer is correct
Smart AP Image Upgrade use a « master » AP in
each FlexConnect Group to download the code.
Other FlexConnect AP download the code from
the master locally

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer configured a BYOD policy that allows for printing on the WLAN using Bonjour services. However, the engineer cannot get printing to work. The WLC firmware is 8.x. What must be implemented on the controller?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
To apply mDNS policy, mDNS snooping is required.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/8-5/config-guide/b_cg85/multicast_broadcast_setup.html#concept_D4C479155D1A4024804CA7230E939D87

Selected Answer: A
mDNS & IGMP snooping

Selected Answer: A
To enable printing using Bonjour services on a wireless network, the WLC must be configured to enable mDNS (multicast Domain Name System) and IGMP snooping.

choices.C: Configure Secure Web Mode Cipher-Option SSLv2.
choices.D: Increase the IGMP Query Interval value
